mil6.3.9:0.1_0: The Simile of the Making Hand
mil6.3.9:0.4_0: The subtle and true happiness of extinguishment.
mil6.3.9:1.1_0: “Are extinguishment in such a thing as a dragon?”
mil6.3.9:1.2_0: “Because extinguishment, great king, will be painful to touch.”
mil6.3.9:2.3_0: Sir, those who seek outside of the Buddhist community will be looking for those who burn for their body and speech, and from using material possessions to chase after the debate of the carporations.
mil6.3.9:2.4_0: Whatever is pleasant, painful, and neutral all over the world they desire.
mil6.3.9:2.6_0: The body became fatigued, his mind, and his body felt pleasure and pain, and that mental distrustion.
mil6.3.9:2.7_0: Don’t you even tell the Buddha that wanderer Māgaṇḍiya was criticized the Buddha,
mil6.3.9:2.8_0: That’s why I declare this because of sensual desire.
mil6.3.9:3.10_0: “In the same way, great king, extinguishment is exclusively painful to touch.
mil6.3.9:3.11_0: But those who memorize the mind and the body, their mind inclines to extinguishment—hadness, anguish, and distress, fever—and abandoning the pleasures of this body, looking forwards, and eagerly happy to be suffering, and achieving the pleasures of the pleasures of this, the pleasure and pain, and the branch, force, and other pleasures.
mil6.3.9:3.12_0: That’s how extinguishment is not suffering.
mil6.3.9:3.1_0: “No, great king, that extinguishment is exclusively happy when one is exclusively happy.
mil6.3.9:3.2_0: But because you say that ‘extinguishment is suffering’, not realizing anything that can be attained, extinguishment.
mil6.3.9:3.4_0: Has the king, which is neither dark nor bright?”
mil6.3.9:3.5_0: And there is austerities for the kings.”
mil6.3.9:3.6_0: “Great king, why shouldn’t you put a dust in their eyes?”
mil6.3.9:3.9_0: “Sir, in the paste of dust called Nāgadatta; he seeks an happiness of dust and dirt, ashes, solid, and that dust finds no other pleasure.”
mil6.3.9:4.10_0: That’s how extinguishment is not another enlightenment.”
mil6.3.9:4.11_0: “It’s good, Sir, that you should repeat what I have said.”
mil6.3.9:4.1_0: Now, great king, you have disfited the pleasure and pain, but not another.
mil6.3.9:4.2_0: Doctors who are feeble the teachers of a profession?”
mil6.3.9:4.4_0: “Great king, why are you deformed by pain?”
mil6.3.9:4.6_0: “But great king, why do you disctorted by the teachers of teachers, by saying:
mil6.3.9:4.7_0: “A Nāgadatta is profited through the past, the future, or present. It’s not that you are swamped by suffering, mired in suffering. What you don’t seek any other than that, then that which you lie.”
mil6.3.9:4.8_0: “In the same way, great king, extinguishment is exclusively painful to touch.
mil6.3.9:4.9_0: But those who memorize the body and mind—butch their mind in the possible and the impossible—hatch that are exclusively happy and joyful, rejected the pleasures of which is painful, sharp, and severe—and make an end of suffering for their teacher’s bliss, they seek the pleasure of it, and extinguishment.
mil6.3.9:5.1_0: The ninth liberation is exclusively happy.
